newsitem.title: USA: US computer network stocks up as outlook brightens.
newsitem.headline: US computer network stocks up as outlook brightens.

text.p: Computer networking stocks saw another day of strong gains Wednesday, benefiting from broad market strength and rising expectations for the sector ahead of a major industry trade show slated for Las Vegas next week.

Analysts said Cisco Systems Inc, the flagship of the group, and the most active stock of the day, gained 2-1/2 to 52-1/2, reflecting investor confidence ahead of the company's earnings quarterly earnings report, due out Tuesday.
Ascend Communications Inc rose 4-1/16 to 45-1/2, as analysts hailed what they said were agressive cost-cutting plans in its Cascade Communications Corp merger.
Cascade shares rose 2-7/8 to 31-1/2 and Fore Systems Inc added 3-1/2 points to 15-1/4. Cabletron Systems Inc rose 1-3/4 to 34-1/2 and Bay Networks Inc was up 1-1/4 to 17-3/4.

The American Stock Exchange's Network Index was up 10.03 to 229.48, the second day of double-digit gains for the index, which last week had hit a year low of just above 200. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up about 47 points in late trading.
Smith Barney analyst Therese Murphy pointed to gains in the broad market, along with anticipation of positive news coming out of the Networld+Interop show in Las Vegas next week.

Analysts and traders said Cisco had traded under a cloud in recent weeks after earnings disappointments from other companies in the sector and rumors that Cisco was gearing up to pre-announce that earnings would fall short of Wall Street expectations in its latest quarter.
With earnings due out on Tuesday and the window for such pre-announcements closed, analysts said investors are confident that there is no disaster pending in Cisco's upcoming earnings results.
The current consensus estimate for Cisco's third quarter ended April 30 is $0.52 per share versus $0.37 per share in the April 1996 quarter, according to First Call.

Smith Barney's Murphy said Ascend share price gains reflected optimism among investors that the company was planning a series of cost-cutting moves, including some lay-offs and sales force combinations, with Cascade.
Ascend had said in an U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission filing April 22 that it planned to take a one-time charge of about $42.2 million to cover cost-cutting moves related to the merger.

Murphy said the $42 million shows that Ascend is serious about its plans to take "some significant costs out" of the combination, and said this could further reduce the dilutive impact of the acquisition on Ascend's future earnings.
She said the substantial merger-related charge boosted confidence that Ascend can produce 1997 results within the guidelines it had announced at the time of the merger.
"That has to make people feel Cascade is not going to be a horrendous drag on Ascend's (results)," Murphy said.
On March 31, Ascend had said it expected the merger to dilute 1997 earnings between $0.05 to $0.10 per share but for the merger to become additive to earnings in the 1998 year.

The once high-flying network group has had to weather a relentless battering since warnings of slowing growth in late January by 3Com Corp and Cascade, among others, spooked investors in the sector as a whole.

The nervousness sent the sector into a slide that caused it to lose more than a third of its value as measured by group indices between late January and mid-April, making it among the worst performing sectors in the stock market during 1997.
